Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Localization in Ad-Hoc Wireless Networks: Investigation into Fusing Dempster-Shafer Theory and Support Vector Machines

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of this project is to perform exploratory investigation into accurate wireless node localization for wireless as hoc networks in realistic network environments, where signal obstruction due to multipath or shadowing is a major concern. To address such practical challenges, this project explores a new and reliable localization technique that mathematically fuses range estimates derived from Received Signal Strength (RSS) and Time Difference Of Arrival (TDOA) measurements.

Intellectual merit:
The intellectual merit lies in the design and implementation of an efficient, hybrid algorithm integrating Dempster-Shafer theory with a state-of-the-art machine-learning tool referred to as Support Vector Machine (SVM). The hypothesis is that SVM-based signal propagation models will possibly help improve the accuracy of range measurements. The proposal entails high-risk as it is applied to real-time environments that are unpredictable and dynamic. If successful, there will be a high-reward in terms of accurately mapping RSS and TDOA signal information into distances, and offering precise node-position with no hardware upgrades whatsoever.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts are reflected in several aspects. This exploratory research will benefit US-based business enterprises that thrive on wireless network applications, particularly in such strategic areas as emergency services and wildlife habitat monitoring. The node localization challenge will be investigated from an interdisciplinary perspective combining the fields of Computer Science and Communications, Geomatics Engineering, and Applied Mathematics. Finally, the proposed research will lead to (i) Creation of new interdisciplinary graduate curriculum for students including minorities and underrepresented groups and (ii) Promotion of interdisciplinary NSF research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Highly accurate localization has been considered as one of the most significant challenges in wireless sensor networks (WSNs). In the last decade, various positioning systems have been invented toward facilitating highly-accurate, low-power, and low-cost localization (or positioning) algorithms. These algorithms find applications in a range of real-life scenarios, including emergency services, navigational systems, and civil and military surveillance. Accuracy and speed are both important traits. For instance, a few seconds of delay in identifying the precise location of injured victims could lead to a life threatening situation.

 

Wireless networks use radio waves and microwaves for maintaining communication channels between devices and users through deployed network nodes consisting of sensors. Each sensor in the deployed network comes with sensing, computation and communication capabilities. Accurate estimation of the location of an unknown network or sensor node is the principal objective of this EAGER project, which involved development, formulation, simulation and validation of novel localization algorithms.

 

Given that a typical sensor node is a small and inexpensive device, low cost and high efficiency were of importance to this project. In order to maintain a reasonable cost, a novel localization scheme that exploited angle of arrival (AOA) and received signal strength (RSS) measurements was proposed. The algorithm was further enhanced by incorporating a unique machine learning statistical paradigm, referred to as the Dempster Shafer Evidence Theory, for the first time.

 

Significant findings in the form of new algorithms and simulation results were either published or being prepared for submission to suitable avenues (e.g. journals). During the course of this project, graduate students were exposed to a variety of technological aspects including (but not limited to) advances in wireless localization; state-of-the-art programming tools for simulation and validation; advanced mathematics and statistics; technical reporting; etc. The obtained scientific outcomes equipped with applied mathematical representation, simulation-based verification, and self-experience, duly constituted the graduate students’ dissertations and publications. Colin Elkin’s thesis demonstrated an improvement of localization accuracy from 80% to over 90% in a particular scenario.
